intro: Abies shastensis var. xanthocarpa, commonly known as the yellow-cedar, is a rare and distinctive variant of the subalpine fir. It is characterized by its yellowish bark and bright green, needle-like leaves that are often coated with a waxy layer. This plant typically grows in high-altitude regions, preferring cool, moist environments with well-drained soil. Its cones are small and reddish, maturing to a brown color, and it produces both male and female cones on the same tree. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.

This variety is found in areas with cool, moist climates and well-drained soils. It typically grows in subalpine and alpine zones, often in association with other coniferous species. The plant is adapted to harsh environmental conditions, including strong winds and limited sunlight. Its distribution is limited to specific geographic regions within these mountain ranges.
